informal_statement:
Suppose that $P = 2^m$ and $Q = 3^n$. Which of the following is equal to $12^{mn}$ for every pair of integers $(m,n)$?

$\textbf{(A)}\ P^2Q \qquad \textbf{(B)}\ P^nQ^m \qquad \textbf{(C)}\ P^nQ^{2m} \qquad \textbf{(D)}\ P^{2m}Q^n \qquad \textbf{(E)}\ P^{2n}Q^m$ Show that it is \bold{E)} P^{2n} Q^m.
formal_statement:
theorem amc12a_2009_p6:
  fixes m n p q :: real
  assumes  "p = 2 powr m"
    and "q = 3 powr n"
  shows "p powr (2 * n) * (q powr m) = 12 powr (m * n)"
formal_code:
(*
  Authors: Wenda Li
*)

theory amc12a_2009_p6 
  imports Complex_Main "HOL-Computational_Algebra.Computational_Algebra"
  "HOL-Number_Theory.Number_Theory"
begin

theorem amc12a_2009_p6:
  fixes m n p q :: real
  assumes  "p = 2 powr m"
    and "q = 3 powr n"
  shows "p powr (2 * n) * (q powr m) = 12 powr (m * n)"
  sorry

end
